case_title: Mst. AISHA and another vs Mrs. SAMAR AFROZE

prosecution: Advocate for Mrs. Samar Afroze (name not specified)
defense: Advocate for Mst. Aisha (name not specified)

complaint_summary: The respondent filed an ejectment application against the petitioner for default in payment of rent.
investigation_summary: The respondent served notice under Section 18 of the Sindh Rented Premises Ordinance, 1979, requiring the petitioner to pay rent within 30 days to the new landlord. The petitioner failed to comply and continued depositing rent in joint names of the previous and new landlords.
judgment_summary: The court upheld the orders of the Rent Controller and Appellate Court, concluding that the petitioner committed willful default in payment of rent despite receiving notices. The petition was dismissed.
legal_arguments: The petitioner argued that the rent deposit in joint names was a technical default and should be condoned.
The court held that after notice under Section 18 of the Sindh Rented Premises Ordinance, 1979, rent must be paid directly to the new landlord.
assets: Property gifted by Akhlaq Hussain to Mrs. Samar Afroze in January 1997.
sections: Section 18 of Sindh Rented Premises Ordinance, 1979
key_issues: Whether the deposit of rent in joint names of previous and new landlords constitutes valid tender.
Whether the petitioner committed willful default in payment of rent.

legal_terms.Technical Default: A minor or procedural failure in compliance with legal requirements.
legal_terms.Willful Default: Intentional failure to fulfill a legal obligation.

words_and_phrases.Valid Tender: Proper payment or offer of payment as required by law.

summary_vector_notes: The case involves a dispute over rent payment following the transfer of property ownership. The petitioner failed to pay rent directly to the new landlord despite receiving notices, leading to an ejectment order upheld by the Sindh High Court. The court dismissed the petition, citing willful default in payment of rent.

key_points.default_reason: Failure to tender rent to new landlord after notice

rent_cases.details: Rent deposited in name of previous owner until February 1997
Rent deposited in joint names of previous owner and respondent

key_points.court_findings: Deposit of rent in joint names not valid tender to new landlord
key_points.tenant_action: Willful default in payment of rent

judgment_excerpts: Tenant required to pay rent within 30 days to new landlord after notice under Section 18.
Deposit of rent in joint names of previous owner and respondent not valid tender.
No illegality or irregularity found in orders of two Courts below.
